   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical decline, now back on paralytics
   and 100% FiO2.  Oxygenation remains tenuous.  Marked hypoxemia.
   Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and possible infection
   and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear as to component of
   GVHD.  No evidence for Pneumocystis, but Bactim now resumed empirically
   after discontinuation last week.  Continue with broad spectrum
   empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole/Bactrim).
   Continue mechanical ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if
   possible, and adjust PEEP as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare to move to
   tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be performed
   safely.  Consider ECMO evaluation, but unable to transfer safely.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to
   ARDS, less likely infection (ex. VAP), but may in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  Continue antibiotics, continue net diuresis.
   Await pending bronchoscopy results.  Need to F/U final BAL report on
   viral cytopathic effects.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing.  Consider trial of NO to determine responsiveness,
   eligibility for longer acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or
   pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Would adjust
   benzodiazepines back to doses comparable to last week.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 43), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 continue TF, but limited by proning position.
   [**Month (only) 51**] need to initiate TPN.

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplant over 200 days ago. The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) and is suffering from progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). 

The patient's respiratory status remains tenuous with marked hypoxemia, and he is back on paralytics and receiving 100% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2). The oxygenation is attributed to ARDS, possible infection, and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It is unclear if GVHD is a contributing factor. 

The patient has been placed on broad-spectrum empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole/Bactrim) and is continuing mechanical ventilation. The goal is to decrease FiO2 to less than 60% if possible and adjust the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) as tolerated to improve oxygenation. The patient's pleural pressures will be monitored, and a chest X-ray (CXR) will be monitored for any changes. If the patient improves, a tracheostomy tube may be considered. 

The patient also has pulmonary infiltrates that are attributed to ARDS and less likely due to infection such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient will continue to receive antibiotics and a net diuresis will be maintained. The

   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS:  The patient shows with improved
   oxygenation while in prone position, but continues to shows overall
   worsening of oxygenation, and is not able to tolerate being in supine
   position for extended periods of time.  APRV ventilation did not result
   in significant improvement in oxygenation this AM.
   - Continue Prone ventilation and adjust vent settings and positions as
   needed with goal PO2>60,  will tolerate pCO2 in 80s.
   - continue to wean FIO2 as tolerated for sats >90%
   - Continue on Propofol, Valium, Methadose and Versed for sedation/pain
   control
   - decrease Midazolam to 10 as tolerated
   - Continue paralysis with Cisatracurium for now
   - F/u with Micro report of CMV findings on prior BAL.

   prone position, but will need to consider other med options and TPN
   feeds (IV access may be a problem) if in prone position for extended
   period of time
   # Sepsis:

   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Wide differential given

   negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative, urine legionella negative.
   Culture from BAL with less than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for

s or organisms. BAL: report of cytopathic effect today on old BAL,

   - Transfuse for Hct < 21

   - renally dose meds

Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL and single cord blood transplantation. She has been experiencing CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient presents with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure. She is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation in the prone position due to hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient's overall oxygenation is worsening, and she is not tolerating the supine position for extended periods. APRV ventilation did not result in significant improvement in oxygenation this morning.
2. Sepsis: The patient initially had sepsis due to multifocal PNA. She is currently afebrile and maintaining BP off pressors. However, her immune system is compromised, making her susceptible to various infections.
3. Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable, but there is no recurrence of GI bleeding. Monitoring Hct and considering transfusion for Hct <21 may be necessary.
4. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's Cr has declined to 0.8, close to baseline. Renal dosing of medications, avoiding nephrotoxins, and continued monitoring of Cr are important.
5. Volume Overload: The patient has significant volume overload since admission, which needs to be managed through di

   Assessment and Plan
   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: Ms. [**Known lastname **] displayed improved
   oxygenation while in prone position with NO. and is not able to
   tolerate being in supine position for extended periods of time.  APRV
   ventilation did not result in significant improvement in oxygenation
   this AM.
   - Continue Prone ventilation and adjust vent settings and positions as
   needed with goal PO2>60,  will tolerate pCO2 in 80s.
   - continue to wean FIO2 as tolerated for sats >90%
   - change NO from 10 ppm to 5ppm if patient tolerates; then consider
   switching off NO. If desaturation, can increase FiO2.
   - Continue on Propofol, Methadone and Versed for sedation/pain control
   - D/C fentanyl and valium
   - D/C phenylephrine
   - Continue paralysis with Cisatracurium (needs to be on for prone
   positioning)
   - F/u with Micro report of CMV findings on prior BAL.
   -Hold PO meds and tube feed including Lamivudine for now given pt. in
   prone position, but will need to consider other med options and TPN
   feeds (IV access may be a problem) if in prone position for extended
   period of time
   - will need to touch base w/ Heme/Onc and ID
   # Sepsis:
   Afebrile.  Maintaining BP off pressors.  Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Wide differential given
   immunosuppression but influenza and other respiratory virus panel
   negative; AFB smear on BAL was negative, urine legionella negative.
   Culture from BAL with less than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for
   PMN
s or organisms. BAL: report of cytopathic effect today on old BAL,
   to be discussed with Micro.  C diff [**11-17**] negative.  B-glucan and
   galactomannan negative x 2.  BAL IF negative for PCP x 2.  .  Pt.
   started on Linezolid due to concern for VRE.
   - f/u ID recs
   - continue Meropenem, Voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**]) - increasing
   LFT's may necessitate changing dosing or d/c'ing medication and
   switching to a different [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - Discuss Antibiotics course w/ ID and BMT as to endpoints?
   - continue Bactrim
   - continue Linezolid to cover for VRE
   - f/u pending blood cultures
   - Increase Solumedrol dose to 40mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue gancyclovir (no acyclovir)
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   - transfuse 1u PRBC today
   -check post xfusion HCT
   # ARF:
   Cr declined to 0.8, close to baseline
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   -continue to monitor Cr
   # Volume overload: Significant volume overload since admission, but
   probably approaching diuresis limits given current CVP 4 and elevated
   bicarb
   - continue lasix drip with goal of even today
   # Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 3234**] shows normal liver, biliary
   system except for gallbladder polyp. DDX includes GVHD vs. meds vs.
   infection
   - LFTs continuing to trend down today  - will continue to monitor given
   Voriconazole use in this patient.  Will re-assess Voriconazole use if
   LFTs continue to climb
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Cont acyclovir ppx
   - Will not need to restart tacrolimus
   - Continue decreased solumedrol dose per heme/onc recs
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   # Hep B:
   - Hold lamivudine for now given in prone position
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Hold tube feeds today as the pt. in prone position.  Will plan to
   restart TPN if the pt. remains in prone position for extended periods
   of time.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a single cord blood transplantation. She has multiple complications including CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis, pneumonia/sepsis, and respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition includes hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, sepsis, anemia, acute renal failure (ARF), volume overload, elevated liver function tests (LFTs), and hepatitis B.

The potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient is already experiencing this condition, and there is a risk of further deterioration in oxygenation and lung function if not properly managed.

2. Sepsis: The patient's immune system is compromised due to the ALL and transplantation, making her susceptible to infections. There is a risk of recurring or new infections leading to sepsis.

3. Anemia: The patient's Hct levels are stable, but there is a risk of recurrence of GI bleeding or ongoing blood loss, which could worsen the anemia.

4. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's Cr levels have declined, indicating improvement, but there is still a risk of renal dysfunction and the need for further monitoring and management.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Remains on
   paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and
   possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear
   as to component of GVHD.  No evidence for Pneumocystis, but Bactim now
   resumed empirically after discontinuation last week.  Continue with
   broad spectrum empirical antibiotics
   (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole/Bactrim).  Continue mechanical
   ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust
   inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve
   oxygenation.  Monitor plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare
   to move to tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be
   performed safely.  Continue NO, with hope to be able to wean to d/c if
   able to maintain adequate SaO2 and pO2.  Considered ECMO evaluation,
   but unable to transfer safely.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to
   ARDS, less likely infection (ex. VAP), but may in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  Continue antibiotics (including Bactrim for
   possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.  Await pending
   bronchoscopy results.  Final BAL report demonstrated viral cytopathic
   effects --> currently on Gancyclovir.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so eligible for longer acting
   [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Would adjust
   benzodiazepines back to doses comparable to last week.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 43), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 continue TF, but limited by proning position.
   [**Month (only) 51**] need to initiate TPN.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently experiencing progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient's respiratory status has shown improvement with the use of inhaled nitric oxide (NO). He remains intubated and mechanically ventilated.

The patient's laboratory results indicate several abnormalities, including elevated white blood cell count, hematocrit, lactate levels, and liver enzymes. His electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with low potassium, magnesium, and phosphate levels. The patient's blood culture results show an infection with viral cytopathic effects, for which he is currently being treated with ganciclovir.

The patient's fluid balance is positive, and there is evidence of right-to-left shunt on cardiac echo. This suggests the presence of pulmonary hypertension, which may contribute to severe hypoxemia. The patient's neurological status is sedated and paralyzed, and his renal function has improved from acute renal failure.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring, including respiratory support, infection control measures, management of fluid balance, and ongoing assessment of his critical care needs.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Remains on
   paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and
   possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear
   as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical ventilation, hope to
   decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust inspiratory and
   expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare to move to
   tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be performed
   safely.  Continue NO, with hope to be able to wean to d/c if able to
   maintain adequate SaO2 and pO2.  Considered ECMO evaluation, but unable
   to transfer safely.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions.  Attributble to
   ARDS, less likely infection (ex. VAP), but may in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  Continue with broad spectrum empirical
   antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including Bactrim for
   possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.  Await pending
   bronchoscopy results.  Final BAL report demonstrated viral cytopathic
   effects --> currently on Gancyclovir.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so eligible for longer acting
   [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Would adjust
   benzodiazepines back to doses comparable to last week.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 43), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 continue TF, but limited by proning position.
   [**Month (only) 51**] need to initiate TPN.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently experiencing progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, with an inhaled nitric oxide (NO) trial showing excellent response in improving oxygenation and interrupting hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory function remains compromised, as indicated by the need for mechanical ventilation and the ongoing administration of NO. Close monitoring of oxygenation parameters and adjusting inspiratory and expiratory pressures will be necessary to maintain adequate gas exchange.

2. Pulmonary Infiltrates: The presence of diffuse pleural effusions suggests ARDS, which may be further complicated by infection, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been initiated, and ongoing fluid balance management is crucial to prevent worsening of pulmonary infiltrates.

3. Hypoxemia: The patient exhibits severe hypoxemia, possibly due to a right-to-left shunt identified on cardiac echo. This may be exacerbated by the development of pulmonary hypertension. Continued monitoring of arterial oxygen saturation (SaO2) and partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) is essential to guide treatment decisions.

4. Neurological Status: The patient is sedated and paralyzed, limiting neurological assessment. Care

   Assessment and Plan
   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: Ms. [**Known lastname **] displayed improved
   oxygenation while in prone position with NO.  There is significant
   improvement in the appearance of lungs on CXR over the past several
   days.   However, she displays significant facial swelling and skin
   breakdown, so she will not be able to tolarate being in RotaProne bed.
   - Switch to  Triadyne II bed from RotaProne
   - Switch to Pressure Control ventilation with the goal tidal volume
   identical to current
   - continue to wean FIO2 as tolerated for sats >90%
   - Continue on Propofol, Methadone and Versed for sedation/pain control
   - Continue paralysis with Cisatracurium. Will attempt to stop in the
   near future.
   - Re-start PO meds and tube feed including Lamivudine for now given pt.
   in prone position.
   - F/u BMT and ID recs
   # Sepsis:
   Afebrile.  Maintaining BP off pressors.  Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Signficant radiographic
   improvement on CXR.  Wide differential given immunosuppression but
   influenza and other respiratory virus panel negative; AFB smear on BAL
   was negative, urine legionella negative.  Culture from BAL with less
   than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for PMN
s or organisms. BAL:
   report of cytopathic effect today on old BAL, to be discussed with
   Micro.  C diff [**11-17**] negative.  B-glucan and galactomannan negative x
   2.  BAL IF negative for PCP x 2.  .  Pt. started on Linezolid due to
   concern for VRE.
   - f/u ID recs, BMT recs
   - continue Meropenem, Voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**])
   - continue Bactrim
   - continue Linezolid to cover for VRE
   - f/u pending blood cultures
   - Continue Solumedrol at 40mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - continue Ggancyclovir
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S

   Cr declined to 0.8, close to baseline
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   -continue to monitor Cr
   # Volume overload: Significant volume overload since admission, given
   improving bicarb, will attempt to diurese 0.5-1 L today.
   - continue lasix drip with goal of 500-1000cc negative today
   # Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 3234**] shows normal liver, biliary
   system except for gallbladder polyp. DDX includes GVHD vs. meds vs.
   infection
   - LFTs slightly up today  - will continue to monitor given Voriconazole

   to climb
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL and single cord blood transplantation. She is currently in the ICU due to pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure. The patient has several medical complications including hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, sepsis, anemia, acute renal failure (ARF), volume overload, elevated liver function tests (LFTs), and chronic immunosuppression.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient's condition is improving while in the prone position, but she is experiencing significant facial swelling and skin breakdown. She will not be able to tolerate being in the RotaProne bed, so a switch to the Triadyne II bed will be made. Pressure control ventilation will also be implemented with the goal of maintaining identical tidal volume.

2. Sepsis: The patient is currently afebrile and maintaining blood pressure off pressors. Initial sepsis was due to multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. There has been significant radiographic improvement on CXR. The wide differential includes influenza and other respiratory viruses, but these have been ruled out. AFB smear on BAL was negative, and urine legionella was negative. Culture from BAL showed less than 1,000 colonies, and Gram stain was negative for PMNs or organisms. Cytopathic effect was observed on old BAL, and further discussion with Micro is pending. C. difficile test

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia) who underwent a single cord blood transplantation. She has been experiencing multiple complications including CMV (Cytomegalovirus) viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE (Vancomycin-Resistant Enterococcus) urinary tract infection, and suspected GVHD (Graft versus Host Disease)-induced hepatitis. The patient presented with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.

The patient is currently in the ICU (Intensive Care Unit) and is intubated, sedated, and not responsive to voice. She is on mechanical ventilation with APRV (Airway Pressure Release Ventilation) mode, and her oxygenation has improved while in the prone position with NO (Nitric Oxide). However, she experiences desaturation when in the supine position.

   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Remains on
   paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and
   possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear
   as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical ventilation, hope to
   decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust inspiratory and
   expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare to move to
   tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be performed
   safely.  Continue NO, with hope to be able to wean to d/c if able to
   maintain adequate SaO2 and pO2.  Considered ECMO evaluation, but unable
   to transfer safely.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  Continue with broad spectrum empirical
   antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including Bactrim for
   possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).

   benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics while paralyzed.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 43), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.

 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old individual with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. The patient is currently experiencing progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient's respiratory failure is attributed to ARDS, possible infection, and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema. 

The patient's oxygenation has improved with the use of inhaled/exogenous nitric oxide (NO). The plan is to continue mechanical ventilation and gradually decrease the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) to less than 60% if possible. Inspiratory and expiratory pressures will be adjusted as tolerated to improve oxygenation. The patient's pleural pressures and chest X-ray will be monitored. If the patient shows improvement, a tracheostomy tube may be considered.

The patient also has pulmonary infiltrates, which are attributed to ARDS and partly related to a positive fluid balance. Broad-spectrum empirical antibiotics will be continued, along with a net diuresis.

Additionally, the patient has evidence of a right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo, contributing to severe hypoxemia. The response to NO suggests that the patient may be eligible for longer-acting pulmonary hypertension treatment. The patient's neurological status is sedated and paralyzed, and benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics will be maintained while the patient is paralyzed.

   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Currently
   off NO, remains on paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by
   measurements) and possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary
   edema.  Unclear as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical
   ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust
   inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve
   oxygenation.  Monitor plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare
   to move to tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be
   performed safely.  If developes profound hypoxemia, resume NO, and
   consider ECMO evaluation (but unable to transfer safely).
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  Continue with broad spectrum empirical
   antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including Bactrim for
   possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).

  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 38), likey due to

   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor

   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor

 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal

   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for

   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.

 continue TF, but limited by proning position.

Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently experiencing progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient has shown an excellent response to inhaled/exogenous nitric oxide (NO) therapy, which has improved oxygenation and reduced hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction. However, he remains on paralytics and is still dependent on mechanical ventilation. The patient's clinical improvement is attributed to ARDS, possible infection, and potential cardiogenic pulmonary edema. There is uncertainty regarding the contribution of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD). 

The patient's respiratory failure is being managed by continuing mechanical ventilation and adjusting inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation. Pleural pressures will be monitored, and a chest X-ray will be evaluated. If the patient improves, a tracheostomy tube may be considered. In case of profound hypoxemia, NO therapy may be resumed, and evaluation for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) may be considered.

The patient's pulmonary infiltrates, which are diffuse and pleural effusions, are thought to be due to ARDS and partly related to a positive fluid balance. Broad-spectrum empirical antibiotics are being continued, including Bactrim for possible Pneumocystis infection.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a single cord blood transplantation. She is currently admitted to the ICU with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure. The patient has multiple medical complications including CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis, hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, sepsis, anemia, acute kidney injury (ARF), volume overload, elevated liver function tests (LFTs), and chronic immunosuppression.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient is currently on assisted ventilation and has shown improvement in oxygenation while in the prone position. Continuous monitoring and weaning of FiO2 as tolerated for sats >90% will be important to prevent further respiratory deterioration.

2. Sepsis: The patient initially presented with sepsis due to multifocal pneumonia. Although she is currently afebrile and off pressors, ongoing monitoring and management of potential infections are crucial due to her immunosuppressed state.

3. Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable, and there is no recurrence of GI bleeding. However, close monitoring of Hct and active T+S are necessary to prevent further complications related to anemia.

4. ARF: The patient's Cr has declined to 0.8, close to baseline.

   Assessment and Plan
   52-year-old female with ALL s/p chemo and single cord blood
   transplantation complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia,
   VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis who presents with
   pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: Ms. [**Known lastname **] displayed improved
   oxygenation while in prone position with NO.  There is significant
   improvement in the appearance of lungs on CXR over the past several
   days.   Currently on APRV with FIO2 100%.
   - wean FiO2 as tolerated for sats >90%
   - Continue on propofol, methadone, midazolam for sedation/pain control
   - Continue paralysis with Cisatracurium. Will reconsider weaning
   cisatracurium daily.
   - F/u BMT and ID recs
   # Sepsis:
   Afebrile. Maintaining BP off pressors. Sepsis initially due to
   multifocal PNA, as seen on CT chest. Signficant radiographic
   improvement on CXR.  Wide differential given immunosuppression but
   influenza and other respiratory virus panel negative; AFB smear on BAL
   was negative, urine legionella negative.  Culture from BAL with less
   than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for PMN
s or organisms. BAL:
   report of cytopathic effect today on old BAL, to be discussed with
   Micro.  C diff [**11-17**] negative.  B-glucan and galactomannan negative x
   2.  BAL IF negative for PCP x 2.  .Pt. started on Linezolid due to
   concern for VRE.  BAL from [**11-10**] showed CMV-like cytopathic effect, and
   CMV viral load from [**2114-11-27**] showed 1160 copies/mL.
   - f/u ID recs, BMT recs
   - continue Voriconazole (day 1 = [**2114-11-19**])
   - continue Bactrim
   - continue Linezolid to cover for VRE
   - f/u pending cultures
   - Continue Solumedrol at 40mg [**Hospital1 **]
   - increase gancyclovir  to 240 mg (5 mg/kg) [**Hospital1 7**]
   # Anemia:
   Hct stable. No recurrence of GI bleeding.
   - monitor Hct
   - Active T+S
   # ARF:
   Cr declined to 0.8, close to baseline
   - renally dose meds
   - avoid nephrotoxins
   - continue to monitor Cr
   # Volume overload: Significant volume overload since admission,
   although this has improved significantly in past few days
   - continue lasix drip with goal of 1.5 L negative today
   # Elevated LFTs: Etiology unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 3234**] shows normal liver, biliary
   system except for gallbladder polyp. DDX includes GVHD vs. meds vs.
   infection
   - LFTs slightly up today  - will continue to monitor given Voriconazole
   use in this patient.  Will re-assess Voriconazole use if LFTs continue
   to climb
   # ALL:
   On chronic immunosuppression s/p single cord blood transplantation.
   - Appreciate BMT recs
   # Hep B:
   - Re-start Lamivudine
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Re-start tube feeds today .

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who has undergone chemotherapy and a single cord blood transplantation. She presents with pneumonia/sepsis, respiratory failure, and multiple complications. The patient is currently intubated and on assisted ventilation with APRV mode. Her oxygenation has improved while in the prone position with NO, and there is significant improvement in the appearance of her lungs on chest X-ray over the past few days. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure, which can lead to further deterioration in oxygenation and potentially progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Sepsis: The patient has sepsis initially due to multifocal pneumonia, as seen on CT chest. She is at risk of developing organ dysfunction or failure if not appropriately managed.
3. Volume overload: The patient has significant volume overload since admission, which needs to be managed to prevent further complications such as pulmonary edema.
4. Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable, but monitoring is required to prevent recurrence of gastrointestinal bleeding.
5. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's creatinine level has declined to 0.8, close to baseline, indicating improvement. However, ongoing monitoring and appropriate medication dosing based on renal function are necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Currently
   off NO, remains on paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by
   measurements) and possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary
   edema.  Unclear as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical
   ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust
   inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve
   oxygenation.  Monitor plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare
   to move to tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be
   performed safely.  If developes profound hypoxemia, resume NO, and
   consider ECMO evaluation (but may not be able to transfer safely).
   [**Hospital3 **] ECMO Team (ICU 7-South) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11245**].
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  [**Month (only) 51**] be component of CMV infection/pneumonia
   (viral cytopathic effects, CMV viremia).  Continue with broad spectrum
   empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including
   Bactrim for possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Maintain
   benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics while paralyzed.  Hope to be
   able to work towards discontinuation of paralytics if tolerates.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 38), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 resume TF, but limited by parlytics.  [**Month (only) 51**] need to
   initiate TPN.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. The patient is currently experiencing progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient has shown an excellent response to inhaled/exogenous nitric oxide (NO) and remains on mechanical ventilation.

The assessment and plan indicate that the patient has several medical complications including respiratory failure, pulmonary infiltrates, hypoxemia, lactic acidosis, alkalemia, acute renal failure, elevated liver function tests (LFTs), sepsis, anemia, hepatitis B, and nutritional support requirements.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include worsening of ARDS and respiratory failure, development of pneumonia or other infections, further decline in renal function, progression of liver dysfunction, worsening of anemia, and potential complications related to hepatitis B.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management of various parameters such as oxygenation, fluid balance, renal function, liver enzymes, nutritional support, and infection control measures. The healthcare team should continue to optimize the patient's respiratory support, closely monitor for signs of infection or sepsis, and address any other emerging complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Currently
   off NO, remains on paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by
   measurements) and possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary
   edema.  Unclear as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical
   ventilation, hope to decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust
   inspiratory and expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve
   oxygenation.  Monitor plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare
   to move to tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be
   performed safely.  If developes profound hypoxemia, resume NO, and
   consider ECMO evaluation (but may not be able to transfer safely).
   [**Hospital3 **] ECMO Team (ICU 7-South) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11245**].
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  [**Month (only) 51**] be component of CMV infection/pneumonia
   (viral cytopathic effects, CMV viremia).  Continue with broad spectrum
   empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including
   Bactrim for possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Maintain
   benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics while paralyzed.  Hope to be
   able to work towards discontinuation of paralytics if tolerates.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 38), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 attributed to ATN.  Resolved.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 resume TF, but limited by parlytics.  [**Month (only) 51**] need to
   initiate TPN.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent a cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently experiencing progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. 

Potential medical complications that can arise from this situation include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory function is severely compromised, which can lead to inadequate oxygenation and carbon dioxide removal. This can result in further deterioration of his condition.

2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Prolonged intubation and mechanical ventilation increase the risk of developing VAP. The patient is already on broad-spectrum antibiotics, but close monitoring for signs of infection is essential.

3. Pneumonia: Given the patient's immunocompromised state due to the ALL and cord blood transplantation, he is at higher risk for opportunistic infections such as fungal or viral pneumonia. Continued monitoring and appropriate antifungal and antiviral prophylaxis should be considered.

4. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has a history of acute renal failure, which could be attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Close monitoring of renal function is necessary, and aggressive fluid management should be continued to prevent further renal impairment.

5. Hepatic dysfunction: Elevated liver enzymes may indicate possible involvement of graft-versus-host disease (GV

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL, who has undergone chemotherapy and a single cord blood transplantation. She is currently in the ICU with pneumonia/sepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS and suspected GVHD. She has also been diagnosed with CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient has been placed on mechanical ventilation and is receiving various treatments including broad-spectrum antibiotics, antiviral medications, and diuretics. She is also on prophylactic medications for stress ulcers, deep vein thrombosis, and vascular-associated pneumonia. The patient's condition remains unstable, and she continues to require intensive care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is attributed to ARDS and possibly GVHD. She is improving with the use of nitric oxide but now has a large left pneumothorax, likely due to barotrauma from high PEEP. The chest tube has been placed, and her vital signs have improved.
2. Sepsis: The patient initially presented with sepsis due to multifocal pneumonia. Although she is currently afebrile and maintaining blood pressure off pressors, her sepsis continues to be a concern. The cause of her sepsis remains unidentified, with negative results for influenza and other respiratory viruses, negative AFB smear

Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL who underwent a single cord blood transplantation. She is currently admitted to the ICU due to complications from chemotherapy, including CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient presents with pneumonia/sepsis and respiratory failure. She is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient has shown improvement in oxygenation while in the prone position with NO, indicating potential complications related to ARDS. Close monitoring and weaning of FiO2 as tolerated for sats >90% are recommended.
2. Sepsis: Although the patient is currently afebrile and maintaining BP off pressors, there is a history of multifocal PNA. The wide differential includes various infectious agents, and further follow-up with BMT and ID recommendations is necessary.
3. Anemia: The patient's Hct is stable, and there is no recurrence of GI bleeding. However, ongoing monitoring of Hct and active T+S are recommended.
4. ARF (Acute Renal Failure): The patient's Cr has declined to 0.8, close to baseline. Renal dosing of medications, avoidance of nephrotoxins, and continued monitoring of Cr are advised.
5. Volume overload: The patient has significant volume overload since admission, although this

   Assessment and Plan
   52 yof ALL s/p cord blood transplant (>200 days) now with progressive
   hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS.
   RESPIRATORY FAILURE
 Overall clinical improvement, with excellent
   response to inhaled/exogenous NO.  NO initiated to improved oxygenation
   and interrupt hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction.  Remains on
   paralytics.  Attributed to ARDS (supported by measurements) and
   possible infection and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema.  Unclear
   as to component of GVHD.  Continue mechanical ventilation, hope to
   decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust inspiratory and
   expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   plerual pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare to move to
   tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be performed
   safely.  If developes profound hypoxemia, resume NO, and consider ECMO
   evaluation (but may not be able to transfer safely).  [**Hospital1 11267**] ECMO Team (ICU 7-South) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11245**].
   PNEUMOTHORAX, LEFT -- tension, attributed to positive pressure
   ventilation/barrotrauma.  Improved with left chest tube.  Maintain
   chest tube while on positive pressure ventilation.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  [**Month (only) 51**] be component of CMV infection/pneumonia
   (viral cytopathic effects, CMV viremia).  Continue with broad spectrum
   empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including
   Bactrim for possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Maintain
   benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics while paralyzed.  Hope to be
   able to work towards discontinuation of paralytics if tolerates.
   GI BLEED -- coffee ground NGT aspirate.  [**Month (only) 51**] represent gastritis or
   PUD.  Monitor exam and serial Hct.  GI consultation if Hct declines.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 33), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).  Improving.
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 Resolved.  Attributed to ATN.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   Approaching baseline weight.
   SEPSIS
 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 hold TF while evaluating for GI bleed.  [**Month (only) 51**] need
   to initiate TPN.  Will require additional central line.
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who underwent cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient has shown an excellent response to inhaled nitric oxide (NO), which has improved oxygenation and interrupted hypoxemia-induced pulmonary vasoconstriction. He remains on mechanical ventilation and paralytics.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumothorax, Left - Tension: The patient developed a left tension pneumothorax attributed to positive pressure ventilation/barrotrauma. It has improved with the placement of a left chest tube.
2. Pulmonary Infiltrates: The patient has diffuse pleural effusions and pulmonary infiltrates, which are attributed to ARDS and net positive fluid balance. There is also a possibility of CMV infection/pneumonia contributing to the infiltrates.
3. Hypoxemia: The patient has severe hypoxemia, which may be due to right-to-left shunt on cardiac echo. This could be related to pulmonary hypertension developing. The patient has responded well to NO therapy and may be eligible for longer-acting treatment.
4. Neurological Status: The patient is sedated and paralyzed, and his neurological status needs to be closely monitored. Benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics will be maintained while he is

   decrease FiO2 to <60% if possible, and adjust inspiratory and
   expiratory pressures as tolerated to improve oxygenation.  Monitor
   pleural pressures.   Monitor CXR.  Would prepare to move to
   tracheostomy tube if improves to allow procedure to be performed
   safely.  If develops profound hypoxemia, resume NO (perhaps low dose),
   and consider ECMO evaluation (but may not be able to transfer safely).
   [**Hospital3 **] ECMO Team (ICU 7-South) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11245**].
   PNEUMOTHORAX, LEFT -- tension, attributed to positive pressure
   ventilation/barrotrauma.  Improved with left chest tube.  Maintain
   chest tube while on positive pressure ventilation.
   PULMONARY INFILTRATES
 diffuse, pleural effusions, much improved
   radiographically.  Attributble to ARDS, and in part related to net
   positive fluid balance.  [**Month (only) 51**] be component of CMV infection/pneumonia
   (viral cytopathic effects, CMV viremia).  Continue with broad spectrum
   empirical antibiotics (linazolid/meropenem/voriconazole-including
   Bactrim for possible Pneumocystis), continue net diuresis.
   HYPOXEMIA
 evidence for right-to-left shunt on recent cardiac echo.
   Likely contributing to severe hypoxemia if pulmonary hypertension
   developing --> excellent response to  NO, so may be eligible for longer
   acting [**Doctor Last Name **].  Monitor SaO2 (maintain >85%) or pO2 (maintain >55 mmHg).
   NEUROLOGICAL STATUS -- sedated, paralyzed.  Maintain
   benzodiazepines/sedation and narcotics while paralyzed.  Hope to be
   able to work towards discontinuation of paralytics if tolerates.
   GI BLEED -- coffee ground NGT aspirate.  [**Month (only) 51**] represent gastritis or
   PUD.  Monitor exam and serial Hct.  GI consultation if Hct declines.
   LACTIC ACIDOSIS
  Persisent, mild elevation.  [**Month (only) 51**] reflect evolving
   sepsis (line-related, VAP, urinary source, hepatobiliary infection)
   need to monitor closely.
   ALKALEMIA -- component of metabolic alkalosis (HCO3= 33), likey due to
   contraction alkalosis in context of active diuresis.  Aggressive
   repletion of Cl (as KCl).  Improving.
   ACUTE RENAL FAILURE
 Resolved.  Attributed to ATN.  Continue monitor
   BUN, creatinine.  Continue lasix drip.
   ELEVATED LFTs
 Possible component of GVHD.  Currently stable.  Monitor
   LFTs.
   FLUIDS
 net positive.  Desire net negative daily fluid balance.
   Approaching baseline weight.

 resolved, remains off pressors.   Initially due to multifocal
   PNA, as seen on CT chest.
   ALL -- s/p cord blood transplantation.   BMTx team following.
   GVHD -- continue medications.  Now on higher dose of steroids (for
   empirical Pneumocystis treatment)
   HEPATITIS B -- Continue lamivudine.
   ANEMIA
 Normocytic.  Hct stable.  Transfuse for Hct < 21.
   NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT
 hold TF while evaluating for GI bleed.  [**Month (only) 51**] need
   to initiate TPN.  Will require additional central line.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old male with a history of ALL who underwent a cord blood transplant over 200 days ago. He is currently experiencing progressive hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS. The patient has shown an excellent response to inhaled/exogenous NO and remains on paralytics. His respiratory failure is attributed to ARDS, possible infection, and possible cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The patient's neurological status is sedated and paralyzed. He has a coffee ground NGT aspirate, which may indicate gastritis or PUD. The patient's lactic acid levels are persistently elevated, possibly due to evolving sepsis. He also has mild alkalemia, likely caused by contraction alkalosis during active diuresis. The patient's acute renal failure has resolved, and he is being monitored for BUN and creatinine levels. His liver function tests show elevated levels, possibly due to GVHD. The patient has a net positive fluid balance and is approaching his baseline weight. He previously had sepsis but is now off pressors. The patient has a history of cord blood transplantation and is being followed by the BMTx team. He is also on medications for GVHD and Hepatitis B. The patient's anemia is normocytic and stable, and he will be transfused if his Hct falls below 21%. Nutritional support is being provided, and additional central line placement may be required. The patient's ICU care includes glycemic control

Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) who has undergone chemotherapy and single cord blood transplantation. She presents with pneumonia/sepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's current condition includes:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure due to ARDS and possible GVHD, which was initially improving on nitric oxide but now worsens with new left-sided pneumothorax. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with FiO2 90% and NO at 5 ppm. Close monitoring of pleural pressures, follow-up chest X-rays, and maintenance of euvolemia are recommended.
2. Sepsis, which has shown improvement with appropriate broad-spectrum antibiotics. Further evaluation is needed to determine the specific causative organism.
3. Anemia, possibly due to gastritis or peptic ulcer disease. Serial hematocrit monitoring is advised, and gastrointestinal consultation may be required if there is a significant decline in hematocrit.
4. Acute renal failure, with creatinine levels improving towards baseline. Renal dose adjustments of medications and avoidance of nephrotoxins are necessary.
5. ALL, with ongoing immunosuppression post cord blood transplantation. BMT recommendations should be followed.
6. Hepatitis B infection, for which lamivudine therapy should be considered.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
- Continued respiratory failure due to ARDS or barotrauma from high P

She has been experiencing complications such as CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient presents with pneumonia/sepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure.

Medical Complications:
1. ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome): The patient is currently on 70% FiO2 and 1 ppm of nitric oxide. The goal is to wean off paralysis, nitric oxide, and FiO2 as tolerated. Close monitoring of SaO2 and pO2 levels is necessary.

2. Pneumothorax: The patient has a large left-sided pneumothorax with a chest tube in place. There is no evidence of recurrence. Further recommendations from thoracic surgery regarding the chest tube and serial chest x-rays will be needed.

3. Sepsis: The patient initially had sepsis due to multifocal pneumonia. She is now maintaining blood pressure off pressors and remains afebrile. The differential diagnosis includes various respiratory pathogens, but initial tests for influenza and other respiratory viruses were negative. AFB smear on bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was negative, and urine Legionella was negative as well. The culture from BAL

- Culture from BAL shows less than 1,000 colonies, Gram stain negative for PMNs or organisms.

Summary of Progress Note:
Ms. [**Known Last Name**] is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL post-chemo and single cord blood transplantation. She presents with pneumonia/sepsis, hypoxemic respiratory failure, ARDS, pneumothorax, sepsis, suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis, GI bleeding, bleeding from IJ insertion site, sub-conjunctival hemorrhage, and chronic immunosuppression.

The patient is currently intubated and sedated, with mechanical ventilation on PRVC/AC mode. Oxygenation has improved, with FiO2 decreased to 70% and only 1 ppm of nitric oxide. She is paralyzed but attempts to wean paralysis, nitric oxide, and FiO2 will be made as tolerated. A chest tube is in place for the large left-sided pneumothorax. There is no evidence of recurrence.

The patient continues to be afebrile and maintains blood pressure off pressors. However, she has a wide range of medical complications, including sepsis initially due to multifocal PNA. The initial workup for the pneumonia was negative for bacterial, viral, and fungal infections. However, the patient's CMV viral load from 11/27 showed 1160 copies/mL.

The patient also has GI bleeding, likely gastritis or PUD, as evidenced by coffee ground NGT aspirate that has now resolved. Her Hct is currently at 23

Summary:
Ms. [Known Last Name] is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL, single cord blood transplantation (>200 days), complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She presents with pneumonia/sepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome): The patient is currently on high FiO2 and nitric oxide. She needs to be closely monitored for oxygenation levels and weaning off nitric oxide and paralysis.
2. Pneumothorax: The patient has a large left-sided pneumothorax, with a chest tube in place. There is no evidence of recurrence, but she will require further evaluation and management by thoracic surgery.
3. Sepsis: Although the patient is currently afebrile and maintaining blood pressure off pressors, she continues to be at risk for sepsis due to her immunocompromised state. Cultures and other investigations should be continued to identify the source of infection.
4. CMV Infection: The patient has a history of CMV viremia and a positive CMV viral load. She should continue to be monitored for any signs of CMV-related complications.
5. GVHD-induced Hepatitis: The patient has suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. She should be monitored for liver function and appropriate management should be provided.

Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL, single cord blood transplantation, and complications such as CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient presents with pneumonia/sepsis and hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient has multiple medical complications including ARDS, pneumothorax, sepsis, GI bleeding, bleeding from IJ insertion site, sub-conjunctival hemorrhage, and Hepatitis B.

Based on the information provided, the potential medical complications that can arise include worsening of ARDS, recurrence of pneumothorax, development of new infections due to immunosuppression, further bleeding episodes, progression of Hepatitis B, and potential complications related to the ongoing treatment and interventions.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's respiratory status, fluid balance, hemodynamic stability, infection parameters, and coagulation profile. Regular communication with the interdisciplinary team, including the BMT and ID consultants, is crucial for managing the complex medical issues in this patient.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient's condition is quite critical. Here is a summary of the information:

- The patient experienced a massive gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, resulting in the insertion of a nasogastric tube (NGT) and administration of blood products.
- The patient underwent an endoscopy, which revealed old clotted blood in the fundus, but the bleeding source could not be clearly visualized due to adherent clots.
- The patient's oxygen saturation levels were in the high 80s on maximum vent settings, prompting the restarting of paralysis with nimbus to address vent dyssynchrony.
- The patient's blood pressure was in the 180s, and respiratory rate was in the 120s-130s.
- The patient required increased levels of nitric oxide (NO) and chest tube suction, but still desaturated to the low 80s on 100% FiO2.
- The patient's ABG results indicated acidemia, and the CXR showed a diffuse process engulfing the lung.
- The patient's heart rate was consistently elevated throughout the night.
- The patient received multiple doses of antibiotics, including cefepime, vancomycin, voriconazole, gancyclovir, piperacillin, and Bactrim.
- The patient received various infusions, including fentanyl, propofol, furosemide, cisatracurium, and midazolam.

Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL, who underwent cord blood transplantation and is currently on chronic immunosuppression. She presents with pneumonia/sepsis, hypoxemic respiratory failure, and a large-volume upper gastrointestinal bleed. She has been experiencing multiple complications including respiratory failure possibly due to ARDS or TRALI, sepsis, gastrointestinal bleeding, bleeding from central line insertion site, sub-conjunctival hemorrhage, and hepatic issues.

The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. She is sedated with propofol, midazolam, methadone, and fentanyl. Her vital signs include a temperature of 38.1Â°C, heart rate of 115 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 113/53 mmHg to 188/87 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 81%. She has bilateral IJ central lines in place.

Her laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, increased platelet count, elevated lactate levels, and abnormal liver function tests. She has negative results for influenza and other respiratory viruses, as well as negative Gram stain from bronchoalveolar lavage. Her blood cultures are pending, and she has been started on Linezolid due to concern for Vancomycin-resistant enterococci.

The patient's assessment and plan include maximizing supportive care for respiratory failure, continuing broad-spectrum

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL who underwent a single cord blood transplantation. She presents with pneumonia/ sepsis, hypoxemic respiratory failure, and a large-volume upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. The patient has been experiencing several medical complications, including ARDS, possible pulmonary thromboembolism (PTX), and sepsis.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure due to multifactorial causes, including ARDS and possible component of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) from blood and fresh frozen plasma (FFP) transfused for the large-volume GI bleed. Oxygenation is worsening, with a saturation level in the high 70s to low 80s on 100% FiO2 and 40 ppm nitric oxide (NO). The patient also has a history of CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE urinary tract infection (UTI), and suspected graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)-induced hepatitis.

The patient's vital signs show tachycardia with a heart rate of 115 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure ranging from 113/53 mmHg to 188/87 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 inspiratory breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation (SpO2) at 81%. The patient's temperature is slightly elevated at 38.1 degrees Celsius

The patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure, requiring increasing ventilatory support. They have a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, electrolyte and fluid disorders, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), type II diabetes mellitus, and cancer. The patient is sedated, intubated, and unable to provide a history. There are concerns about potential complications related to volume overload, hypotension, and worsening respiratory status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pulmonary Complications: The patient's worsening respiratory status and ARDS indicate a high risk for further pulmonary complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or acute exacerbation of ARDS.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's hypotension and the use of vasopressors suggest a risk for cardiac complications like myocardial infarction or heart failure.
3. Renal Complications: With the presence of fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances, there is a risk for renal dysfunction or acute kidney injury (AKI).
4. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state due to cancer and prolonged ICU stay increases the risk for infections, including catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI) or hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: Although the active bleeding has been addressed, the patient still has a risk for re-bleeding or development of stress ulcers, which can lead to further gastrointestinal bleeding.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL, who underwent a single cord blood transplantation. She has been on chronic immunosuppression and is currently presenting with pneumonia/sepsis, hypoxemic respiratory failure, large-volume upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed, and possible transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI). The patient's condition has been complicated by CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE urinary tract infection (UTI), and suspected graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)-induced hepatitis.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9Â°C, heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure of 112/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 83% on 100% FiO2. The patient is intubated and sedated, with chemosis, conjunctival hemorrhage, and marked swelling of the eyelids.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 15.6 K/uL, thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 204, anemia with a hemoglobin level of 10.8 g/dL, elevated lactate levels, and abnormal liver function tests. Blood cultures are pending, and the patient is currently receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics.

Summary:
The patient is a 52-year-old female with a history of ALL, who underwent a single cord blood transplantation over 200 days ago. She has been experiencing multiple complications including CMV viremia, streptococcal bacteremia, VRE UTI, and suspected GVHD-induced hepatitis. The patient is currently presenting with pneumonia/sepsis, hypoxemic respiratory failure, upper GI bleed, and possible TRALI from blood and FFP transfusions. She has been intubated, sedated, and on mechanical ventilation. Her oxygenation and ventilation are worsening despite maximal therapy. The prognosis is very poor.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial and could be due to ARDS, pneumothorax (PTX), and possibly TRALI from blood and FFP transfusions. Oxygenation and ventilation are worsening despite maximal therapy.
2. Sepsis: The patient initially had sepsis due to multifocal pneumonia. She is now hypothermic and has a wide differential given her immunosuppressed state. Initial tests for influenza and other respiratory viruses were negative, and AFB smear on BAL was negative as well. The culture from BAL showed less than 1,000 colonies, and Gram stain was negative for PMNs. Cytopathic effect was observed on old BAL, and CMV viral load was high.
3. GI Bleeding: The patient continues to have melena
